Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 54024-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2020 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: Customized Low-
Carbon Development Models in Rural and Small- 
and Medium-Sized Towns  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the deployment of low-
carbon energy supply infrastructure in rural areas and small- and medium-sized towns (SMTs) in 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC) by identifying optimal low-carbon models for those areas 
and associated policy recommendations. 
 
2.  The TA is included in the list of projects agreed upon by the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) and the Government of the PRC on 22 January 2020.1 It is consistent with the strategic 
priorities of ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC, 2016–2020.2 It is also aligned with 
the government’s priority of supporting low-carbon growth in its Thirteenth Five-Year Plan, 2016–
2020.3 Increasing low-carbon energy sources in rural areas and SMTs will contribute to the PRC’s 
efforts to peak its carbon dioxide emissions by 2030 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2060. The 
TA will support a key strategic pillar of ADB’s Strategy 2030—tackling climate change—by 
accelerating the development of low greenhouse gas (GHG) emission technologies.4 The project 
will contribute to Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 13 by taking urgent action to combat 
climate change and its impacts; SDG 7 by ensuring access to affordable, reliable, sustainable, 
and modern energy for all; and SDG 9 by upgrading infrastructure with increased efficiency and 
adoption of clean technologies. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  In 2015, ADB and the government agreed to establish a multiyear lending program (2015–
2020) to reduce air pollution in the greater Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei (BTH) region.5  The program 
succeeded in improving energy efficiency and increasing the share of clean energy, leading to 
improved air quality and reduced GHG emissions in large urban cities. 
 
4.  The BTH program, and other efforts, are achieving results in large urban cities  by 
deploying clean and efficient energy technologies that emit fewer GHG emissions. However, the 
deployment progress is slow in the rest of the country, including in rural areas and small- and 
medium-sized towns (SMTs).6 These areas have limited financial resources, capacities, and 
knowledge regarding clean and energy efficient technologies compared with the large urban cities.  
 
5.  The current national clean energy deployment guidelines target large urban cities and do 
not consider the unique conditions of rural areas and SMTs, which generally bear the higher cost 
for their low-carbon energy supply than large urban cities.7 To overcome these challenges, the 
government needs to formulate policies and measures to ensure affordable renewable energy 
 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 7 September 2020. 
2  ADB. 2016. Country Partnership Strategy: People’s Republic of China, 2016–2020—Transforming Partnership: 
People’s Republic of China and Asian Development Bank. Manila. 
3  Government of the People’s Republic of China, National Development and Reform Commission. 2015. The 13th 
Five-Year Plan for Economic and Social Development of the People’s Republic of China: 2016–2020. Beijing. 
4  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
5  ADB. 2015. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Policy-Based Loan 
to the People’s Republic of China for the Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei Air Quality Improvement–Hebei Policy Reforms 
Program. Manila. The greater BTH region refers to Beijing and Tianjin municipalities; the Hebei, Henan, Liaoning, 
Shandong, and Shanxi provinces; and the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. 
6  The TA project defines SMTs by residential population; a small town has a residential population of less than 0.5 
million, and a medium-sized town has a population between 0.5 million and 1.0 million. 
7  Government of the People’s Republic of China. 2017. Guidelines on Promoting Clean Heating Supply in Urban Areas 
in Northern China. Beijing.

2 
development in rural areas and SMTs. 
 
6.  Several ADB TA projects have supported low-carbon development in rural areas in the 
PRC.8 Those projects aimed to address specific local rural clean energy supply issues, focusing 
on technology aspects. The activities included maximizing the use of rich clean energy resources 
in rural areas by using government-financed advanced technology such as renewable energy 
output forecasting. Those technology-focused studies identified that non-technology aspects like 
policies also need to be analyzed because they can be fundamental barriers in their low-carbon 
development plans of rural areas and SMTs. This TA will focus more on policy reforms to enable 
the adoption of non-fossil solutions and deliver sustainable economic solutions without relying on 
government subsidies.  
 
7.  The proposed solutions would  encourage the private sector to finance renewable energy 
projects and enable sustainable low-carbon energy development in rural areas and SMTs. To 
address the financing challenges of clean energy development in poor rural economies, policy 
support to improve the business environment (e.g., aggregated demand response services and 
innovative financing practices using financial technology [fintech]) will be explored by the TA 
consultant when designing the models. After its success in large urban cities like the greater BTH 
region, the central government aims to strengthen clean energy development in rural areas and 
SMTs.9 Because local condition varies among the rural villages and SMTs, no single low-carbon 
development model could address the above challenges. Based on careful analysis of policies to 
adopt new technologies as well as financing practices for the specific local condition, low-carbon 
development models need to be developed. 
 
8.  The BTH program succeeded in reducing dependence on coal, but the region is still reliant 
on natural gas. Although natural gas is cleaner than coal, it still emits GHG and is not acceptable 
for accessing climate financing. Recognizing these limitations of relatively lower carbon fossil 
fuels such as natural gas, this TA will focus on developing next generation clean energy, providing 
direction to increase the share of renewable energy, and expanding the geographical impact to 
the entire country. The TA will contribute to the government's green development targets, such 
as carbon emission peaking by 2030 and carbon neutrality by 2060. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: (i) renewable energy interventions in rural 
areas increased,10 and (ii) the low-carbon modernized energy supply in SMTs increased.11 The 
TA will have the following outcome: policy landscape for investing in low-carbon energy supply 
infrastructure in rural areas and SMTs improved.12 The outcome has the following indicator since 
 
8  ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for the Gansu Rural Clean Energy Development 
Project. Manila; ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for the Renewable Energy 
Development in Qinghai. Manila; ADB. 2017. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for the Study 
on Clean Energy Supply for the Rural Areas in the Greater Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei Region. Manila; and ADB. 2018. 
Technical  Assistance  to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  the  Advanced  Renewable  Energy  Technology 
Demonstration. Manila. 
9  Government of the PRC, National Energy Administration. Forthcoming. New Energy Law of the People’s Republic 
of China. Beijing. 
10 Government of the PRC. 2018. Strategic Planning for Rural Revitalization (2018–2022). Beijing. 
11 Government of the PRC, National Development and Reform Commission and National Energy Administration. 2017. 
Strategy for the Revolution in Energy Production and Consumption. Beijing.  
12 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
the TA is expected to provide policy recommendations: at least one national or two local 
government policies or guidelines that incorporate TA recommendations promoting the adoption 
of a low-carbon energy supply for implementation.  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
  
10.  Output  1:  Research  on  optimal  models  with  policies  and  guidelines  for  rural 
vitalization via low-carbon energy infrastructure in rural areas completed. The output will 
focus on local policies and guidelines for affordable low-carbon energy supply in rural areas, 
lowering the barrier for private sector to enter the market. The following will be evaluated: 
(i) optimal technical models of rural vitalization via renewable energy deployment; (ii) optimal 
economic models of rural vitalization via renewable energy deployment, including an innovative 
financing scheme suitable for rural areas; and (iii) a policy and/or guidelines on low-carbon energy 
supply infrastructure in rural areas for government decision makers. The research will use sample 
villages as case studies to analyze the models. The analysis results will be disseminated at 
workshops and summarized in a knowledge product. The policy recommendations obtained in 
the output are expected to be incorporated in national and/or local government clean energy 
policies. 
 
11.  Output 2: Research on optimal models and needed policies for low-carbon energy 
supply infrastructure in small- and medium-sized towns completed. The output focuses on 
modernizing energy supply infrastructure, improving energy efficiency, reducing GHG emissions, 
and lowering low-carbon energy supply costs in SMTs. Solutions will consider local conditions, 
including the rapidly growing economy and energy demands of SMTs. The TA will also explore 
emerging technologies such as digital technology and micro-grids. This output will define (i) an 
energy modernization scheme for SMTs in northern and southern PRC, and (ii) the relevant 
policies needed to support energy modernization in SMTs. The research will use sample towns 
as  case  studies  to  analyze  the  models.  Findings  will  be  disseminated  at  workshops  and 
summarized in a knowledge product. The policy recommendations obtained in the output are 
expected  to  be  incorporated  into  the  clean  energy  policies  of  the  national  and/  or  local 
governments. 
 
12.  Knowledge dissemination. A policy brief based on the technical study will be developed 
under the TA, and printed publications will be circulated in workshops and conferences. The 
publications will also be uploaded digitally on ADB’s website to maximize readership. The number 
of hard copies will be agreed upon with the executing agency during TA implementation. The 
major target audience includes relevant government entities.  
 
13.  This TA will focus on the policy aspects because the government identified them as 
fundamental gaps in their low-carbon development plans in rural areas and SMTs. The TA will 
contribute towards the government’s efforts to achieve carbon peaking in 2030 and carbon 
neutrality by 2060. The TA is expected to deliver policy recommendations to promote clean 
energy development in rural areas and SMTs, achieving non-fossil and sustainable economic 
solutions without government subsidies. ADB will also share the knowledge it has obtained from 
resources like the Asian Clean Energy Forum. Although the TA design does not directly involve 
a gender component, the TA will explore solutions that benefit women, such as improving the 
health conditions of those that work in household kitchens by installing low-carbon energy fueled 
heaters and cooking stoves to improve  air quality.

4 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,100,000, of which (i) $238,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (other sources); and (ii) $750,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Climate Change Fund.13 The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 2.  
 
15.  The Climate Change Fund (CCF) will finance consulting services and equipment for 
eligible activities indicated in the fund’s implementation guidelines.14 
 
16.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, information, and documents relevant to conduct the TA, and other in-kind 
contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB’s East Asia Department will select, supervise, and 
evaluate consultants. The National Energy Administration (NEA) will be the executing agency. 
NEA’s Department of International Cooperation will be the implementing agency with support from 
local authorities from the sample villages and towns used as case studies in the TA.  
 
18.  Implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

Source: ADB estimates. 
 
19.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and  its associated procurement staff instructions.15 
Because the TA requires consultants to be familiar with the PRC's local conditions, e.g., local 
policies and regulations, the majority of experts will be national. ADB will recruit two national 
consulting firms to deliver the two outputs using quality- and cost-based selection with a 90:10 
quality–cost ratio and a full technical proposal. The estimated input will be 48 person-months of 
national consultants over 18 months. ADB will recruit four international individual consultants, 
including team leaders via individual consultant selection. International experts will be recruited 
through an individual selection method to supplement knowledge that local experts may lack, 
including knowledge of cutting-edge business models for integrated low-carbon energy suppliers 
in rural and underdeveloped SMTs and top-notch climate change impact analysis schemes. The 
total estimated input is 17 person-months. Time-based contracts will be considered for the firms 
and individual consultants. The consulting firms will organize and conduct workshops. Resource 
persons may also be recruited as expert presenters at workshops. Lump sum and/or output-based 
contracts will be considered to engage resource persons. 
 
20.  TA implementation will follow the additional monitoring and reporting requirements specific 
to the CCF (footnote 14). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $988,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China for Customized Low-Carbon Development Models 
in Rural and Small- and Medium-Sized Towns, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
15 Terms of reference for consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Research on optimal models with policies and guidelines for rural vitalization via low-carbon 
energy infrastructure in rural areas completed  
1.1 Recruit consultants, identify case study locations, and hold TA kick-off meeting (Q2 2021) 
1.2 Collect data including energy consumption behavior, policy and regulation on low-carbon energy 
supply service, and market overview of the energy supply service in the sample locations (Q2 2021) 
1.3 Assess optimal economic and technical models for poverty alleviation with low-carbon development in 
the study locations, deliver a TA interim report, and hold a TA interim workshop (Q4 2021) 
1.4 Recommend the optimal models with necessary policy modifications and energy supply service 
practices including innovative financing mechanism (Q2 2022) 
1.5 Develop the study result report (Q4 2022) 
1.6 Organize the final TA workshop to disseminate the result (Q4 2022) 
2.  Research on optimal models and needed policies for low-carbon energy supply infrastructure 
in small- and medium-sized towns completed  
2.1 Recruit consultants, identify case study locations, and hold a TA kick-off meeting (Q2 2021) 
2.2 Collect data including energy consumption behavior, policies and regulations on low-carbon energy 
supply services, and a market overview of the energy supply service in the sample locations (Q2 
2021) 
2.3 Assess economically optimal low-carbon energy development models suitable for the sample 
locations, deliver a TA interim report, and hold a TA interim workshop (Q4 2021) 
2.4 Recommend the optimal models and needed policies for low-carbon energy infrastructure in SMTs 
(Q2 2022) 
2.5 Develop the study result report (Q4 2022) 
2.6 Organize the final TA workshop to disseminate the result (Q4 2022)

The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, information 
and documents relevant to conduct the TA, and other in-kind contributions. The value of the government contribution 
is estimated to account for 10% of the total TA cost.

d  A survey firm or institute will be recruited to undertake the survey. Goods will include tablets for conducting the survey 
and software design costs for recording survey results. The consulting firm will procure the goods following the ADB 
Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time). The purchased goods will be turned over to the executing 
agency at TA completion. 
e  Tablets to be used for the survey will be procured under the TA. The purchased equipment will be turned over to the 
executing agency at completion of TA activities.  
f   The knowledge product of the study finding will be disseminated. Printed publications will be circulated in workshops 
and  conferences.  The  number  of  hard  copies  will  be  agreed  upon  with  the  executing  agency  during  TA 
implementation. The major target audience includes relevant government entities.
